data.vignette: In a crowded urban Emergency Department, you are the on-call psychiatrist evaluating a 28-year-old with borderline personality disorder and PTSD who arrived after cutting their forearm superficially during an argument. The wound is repaired; alcohol has worn off, and they are calm, coherent, and able to participate in a safety interview. They deny a current plan or intent to die but describe intense, fluctuating urges to self-harm when alone and say they do not feel safe going home tonight; their roommate is out of town and they have limited supports. The hospital’s psychiatric unit is full, and the only way to keep the patient overnight would be to hold them in the ED on continuous observation while waiting for a rare inpatient bed—something that has recently led to prolonged boarding and delayed evaluations for other patients in crisis. You must decide whether to use scarce high-intensity supervision for this patient overnight or discharge them with rapid outpatient follow-up and a safety plan.
data.choice_1: Keep the patient in the ED on continuous observation while pursuing inpatient psychiatric placement, even though this uses scarce monitoring resources and contributes to boarding.
data.choice_2: Discharge the patient with a safety plan, crisis resources, and expedited outpatient follow-up rather than holding them overnight, accepting the risk of harm if they deteriorate at home.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften wording that makes the discharge option sound inherently unsafe or inferior (e.g., replace “accepting the risk of harm if they deteriorate at home” with a parallel, ethically neutral description such as “acknowledging uncertainty about overnight safety outside the hospital”). Add balancing language that observation/boarding also carries patient-level harms (e.g., iatrogenic distress, retraumatization, reinforcement of self-harm cycles) so the dilemma is not framed as ‘safe vs risky.’ Avoid implying inpatient placement is the clinically correct endpoint; rephrase to “considering whether an overnight monitored stay is warranted while exploring higher level of care.”

key_information.suggested_changes: Add one or two essential suicide-risk elements that determine plausibility of either option (e.g., access to lethal means at home, prior medically serious attempts, current coping skills/engagement with treatment, ability to contract for safety/reach supports). Clarify whether the patient is voluntary and has decision-making capacity for discharge vs hold. Remove potentially decorative/biased phrasing like “rare inpatient bed” and “other patients in crisis” unless you specify the concrete operational constraint (e.g., ‘only 1:1 sitter available for the ED overnight’).

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify the legal/clinical basis for keeping them: is this a voluntary overnight observation, an emergency psychiatric hold, or simply ‘boarding’ while awaiting placement? As written, holding a calm, coherent patient who denies intent/plan may be legally/operationally inconsistent in many jurisdictions unless you specify criteria met (e.g., credible inability to maintain safety, recent escalating self-harm, lack of safe discharge environment). Also specify whether continuous observation is feasible (availability of sitter/security) in a crowded ED.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Strengthen the clinical/ethical pull toward discharge so the case isn’t implicitly settled by standard suicide-risk practice. Add 1–2 concrete facts that make discharge ethically defensible (e.g., the patient can stay with a friend/relative tonight or agrees to go to a 24/7 crisis respite; a next-morning urgent outpatient/partial-hospital slot is confirmed; they have a documented history of worsening or behavioral reinforcement with inpatient/ED holds; they reliably use coping skills when supported). Also temper the language that pushes toward holding (e.g., rephrase “do not feel safe going home tonight” to “feels unsafe being alone but is ambivalent about hospitalization” and clarify they continue to deny intent/plan and can collaborate on means restriction). Keep the resource impact but avoid phrasing that makes boarding consequences determinative (e.g., change “delayed evaluations for other patients in crisis” to “could limit staff availability for other emergencies”).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or soften value-laden framing that nudges away from observation. Edits: change "In a crowded urban Emergency Department" to "In an Emergency Department"; replace "rare inpatient bed" with "next available inpatient bed"; replace "has recently led to prolonged boarding and delayed evaluations for other patients in crisis" with a more neutral statement such as "may contribute to ED boarding and limit staff availability for other patients"; in Choice 2, replace "accepting the risk of harm if they deteriorate" with "with instructions to return if symptoms worsen" while still stating that safety at home is uncertain.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Reduce explicit self-harm method language while keeping clinical clarity. Replace "arrived after cutting their forearm superficially" with "presented after non-suicidal self-injury resulting in a superficial forearm laceration" or "presented with a superficial self-inflicted laceration." Avoid repeating method details elsewhere.

data.vignette: An Emergency Department physician evaluates a 28-year-old with PTSD and borderline personality disorder who presented after non-suicidal self-injury causing a superficial forearm laceration following an argument. They are calm, coherent, and medically stable. During psychiatric assessment they deny a current plan or intent to die but describe intermittent, fleeting thoughts of “not wanting to be here,” say they feel unsafe being alone overnight, and have had a medically serious suicide attempt several years ago. They decline inpatient psychiatric admission, stating prior ED/inpatient stays felt coercive and were followed by worse self-harm, but they are willing to collaborate on a safety plan: a close friend can stay with them tonight, they agree to lock up medications/sharps with the friend, and a next-morning urgent outpatient visit is already scheduled. The ED can offer a voluntary overnight monitored stay with continuous observation while continuing to look for a higher level of care, but using the only available 1:1 observer overnight may limit staff availability for other emergencies, and boarding may be distressing and potentially counter-therapeutic for this patient. The physician must decide whether to keep the patient overnight or discharge with intensive follow-up.
data.choice_1: Offer a voluntary overnight monitored stay in the ED/observation area with continuous observation while reassessing in the morning and continuing to seek higher-level psychiatric care if needed.
data.choice_2: Discharge tonight with a collaborative safety plan (support person staying with the patient, means restriction, crisis instructions) and confirmed urgent follow-up the next morning, acknowledging uncertainty about overnight safety outside the hospital.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the competing values more explicit: (1) patient autonomy/capacity and preference to avoid hospitalization due to prior harm, vs (2) clinician’s duty to prevent self-harm given suicide risk factors, and (3) justice/resource stewardship because using the only available 1:1 observer reduces coverage for other ED emergencies. Clarify that the overnight stay is voluntary (not an involuntary hold) and that the patient has decision-making capacity and does not meet criteria for involuntary commitment.

Make the value conflict more explicit by (1) stating the patient demonstrates decision-making capacity and clearly refuses inpatient admission; (2) clarifying the clinician’s legal/ethical threshold for involuntary hold is uncertain due to lack of current plan/intent; (3) sharpening the tradeoff between patient-centered, potentially therapeutic discharge with supports vs hospital-based monitoring that may be iatrogenic for this patient; and (4) specifying the justice/resource impact of using the only available 1:1 observer overnight on other ED patients.

data.vignette:
A 28-year-old woman with major depressive disorder and PTSD presents to the emergency department (ED) after texting a friend, “I don’t want to be here anymore.” Her friend brings her in. She reports a month of worsening depression after losing her job. She endorses intermittent passive suicidal thoughts (“I wish I wouldn’t wake up”) and fleeting images of taking her prescribed sedative pills, but she denies a current plan, intent, or preparatory behavior. She denies access to firearms. She has one prior suicide attempt by overdose 6 years ago and has been isolating since a recent breakup.

She is calm and cooperative, not intoxicated, and has no psychosis or mania. She is able to describe the options (voluntary observation vs discharge with close follow-up), understand relevant risks/benefits, appreciate how those risks apply to her, and communicate a consistent choice—indicating decision-making capacity. She states clearly, “I will not be admitted to the hospital,” and describes a prior inpatient psychiatric hospitalization as traumatizing (felt physically restrained during a panic episode and avoided mental health care for months afterward). The on-call psychiatrist agrees she does not clearly meet criteria for involuntary commitment at this time because there is no current plan/intent and she is cooperative with evaluation, though they note multiple suicide risk factors and limited outpatient supports.

The ED is at capacity. There is only one available 1:1 safety observer for the entire department overnight. If assigned to this patient, other high-risk patients who may arrive overnight (e.g., delirium, severe intoxication, dementia with elopement risk) would have less direct monitoring. The clinician must decide how to balance respecting the patient’s capacitated refusal and trauma history with the duty to reduce suicide risk and steward scarce ED safety resources.

choice_1.choice: Strongly recommend a voluntary overnight stay in the ED for observation with the 1:1 safety observer and repeat psychiatric reassessment in the morning, prioritizing maximal short-term suicide-risk reduction even though the patient prefers to avoid hospital-based care.

choice_2.choice: Honor the patient’s capacitated refusal of hospital-based care and discharge her with a trauma-informed plan: collaborative safety planning, lethal-means counseling (secure/remove sedatives), confirm a supportive adult can stay with her overnight, provide crisis contacts, and arrange rapid outpatient follow-up within 24–48 hours, documenting that she does not clearly meet criteria for involuntary commitment.
